questions.question: Question 1: What is the hypothesis which states that an apparent effect is only due to chance, called as?
questions.explanation:
The hypothesis that an apparent effect is only due to chance is a null hypothesis. If this is rejected 
as false, we have an alternative hypothesis.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the significance level in hypothesis testing called as?
questions.explanation: Significance level in hypothesis testing is called alpha level () or criterion.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the p value?

options.a: Probability of declaring a significant difference when there is none in reality
options.b: Probability of declaring a significant difference when it is actually present
options.c: Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present
options.d: Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is present

questions.explanation:
p-value can be defined as the probability of declaring a significant difference when there is none in 
reality.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is false about the p-value?

options.a: It is equal to the probability of committing a type I error
options.c: It is the chance that the presence of difference is concluded when actually there may be none
options.d: When the p value is less than , the result is statistically significant

questions.explanation:
The power of a test is 1 – beta. The p value is the probability that a type I error is being made. It is the chance that the presence 
of difference is concluded when actually there may be none. When the p value is less than , the 
result is statistically significant.

questions.question:
Question 5: A randomized control trial comparing the efficacy of two chemotherapy regimens for 
Hodgkin's lymphoma showed that their difference is statistically significant with p < 0.001. 
However, in reality the two drugs do not differ in their efficacy. What type of error is this an 
example of?
questions.explanation:
This is an example of a type I error. In this scenario, let us take the null hypothesis as the efficacy of two drugs being the same, which 
as the question states, is true in reality. The alternative hypothesis will then be that one drug is 
better than the other. The questions states that p-value was found to be < 0.001, which is statistically significant and 
so the null hypothesis is rejected. But we already know that the null hypothesis is true and we are 
forced to accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false. When an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it 
is called as a type I error or an alpha error or a false positive error. 853

questions.question:
Question 6: An investigator is conducting a study to assess the effect of a mood stabiliser on patients with 
bipolar I disorder. What does it mean if the difference is significant in the results?

options.a: p > 0.05 and it is likely by chance
options.b: p > 0.05 and it is unlikely by chance
options.c: p < 0.05 and it is unlikely by chance
options.d: p < 0.05 and it is likely by chance

questions.explanation:
When the difference is significant, it means that the difference is unlikely by chance and p will be 
 0.05.

questions.question:
Question 7: While assessing the effect of a new intervention for type II DM, you obtain the p-value of the 
study as 0.023. Based on this observation, what is your inference?

options.a: Null hypothesis is accepted and the study is rejected
options.b: Null hypothesis is rejected and the study is accepted
options.c: Null hypothesis is accepted and the study is accepted
options.d: Null hypothesis is rejected and the study is also rejected

questions.explanation:
By convention, if the p value  0.05, the difference is said to be statistically significant. Thus, the 
null hypothesis is rejected and the study is accepted.

questions.question:
Question 9: You are conducting a randomised clinical trial to see if a new drug 'A' has better efficacy than 
the standard drug 'B', in patients with grade III hypertension. While analysing the results of 
this study, you conclude that no difference exists between the two. But in reality, a difference 
between them truly exists. What type of error are you making?
questions.explanation:
Type II errors are when an alternative hypothesis is rejected when it is true. In this scenario, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference and the alternative hypothesis is 
that there is a difference. We failed to reject the null hypothesis that says there is no difference, and so we are making a 
type II error. In other words, we have rejected the alternative hypothesis that there is an 
difference when it is true.

questions.question: Question 10: Power of a study is the ability of a test to
questions.explanation: The power of a study is its ability to avoid or decrease beta errors or type II errors. The statistical power of a test is represented by 1 – .

questions.question:
Question 11: A randomised control trial is being conducted in patients with direct inguinal hernia, to 
compare the outcomes of a new surgery 'A' and the gold standard surgery 'B'. The p value of 
this trial is found to be 0.04. What can we conclude from this?

options.a: Type II error is small and we can accept the findings of the study
options.b: The probability of false negative conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%
options.c: The power of the study to detect the difference between operation A and B is 96%
options.d: The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

questions.explanation:
Since the p-value of the study is found to be 0.04, we can infer that the probability of a false 
positive conclusion that the operation A is better than B is 4%. In this scenario, the p value is 0.04 which makes it, by convention, statistically significant. We can 
reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis that operation A is better than 854

questions.question:
Question 12: You are an investigator conducting a statistical test. You obtain the p value as 0.01 for your 
study. What does this mean?

options.a: The probability of finding a significant difference is 1%
options.b: There is a 1% probability that the difference is not by chance
options.c: The difference is not significant 1% of times and significant 99% of times
options.d: The power of the test used is 99%

questions.explanation:
If the p-value = 0.01, then the difference is not significant 1% of the time and significant 99% of 
the time. In other words, there is a 99% probability that the difference is not by chance and there is a 1% 
probability that the difference is only by chance.

questions.question:
Question 13: In a well-designed cancer study, similar remission rates were obtained for a new treatment 
(33.2%) and the usual treatment (32.2%), with the p-value being 0.04. Which of the following 
statements is true regarding the study?
questions.explanation:
As the p-value is 0.04, we can conclude that the new treatment is more effective than the usual 
treatment. Even though both treatments have similar rates of remission, a valid statistical test is required to 
determine the difference in their effectiveness. Statistically, p-value < 0.05 implies that the 
alternate hypothesis is true. In this scenario, we can consider: • Null hypothesis: Both the treatments are equally effective (in other terms, there is no difference 
between the effect of the two treatments). • Alternative hypothesis: New treatment is more effective than the usual treatment. As the p-value is 0.04, which is statistically significant (<0.05), the null hypothesis is rejected 
and the alternative hypothesis is accepted. Hence the new treatment is more effective than the 
usual treatment. 855
